instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7012: What is D7012? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year model macbook airs, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- Green light, no fan spin but sometimes boots. VERY temperamental
threads.message:
I have a really odd one. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in with no sign of life except green light. Pulls around 0.018A  from DCPS. Sometimes it turns on but most times it's dead. 

Used a thermal cam and it was able to detect that the ISL is 1 degree warmer than the rest of the board consistently but that probably doesn't mean much.

Board looks pristine but I do suspect it's been through an ultrasonic before because of the discolouration of the test points and the board has definitely been removed before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- Green light, no fan spin but sometimes boots. VERY temperamental
threads.message:
have just been told that they have used a fake charger and this happened. 

I tested something myself, I used a original charger and it 100% doesnt work. when I use my DCPS with a macbook cable, it works 20% of the time but only in a certain direction it seems. Yes have tested new DC in board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- Green light, no fan spin but sometimes boots. VERY temperamental
threads.message: when it does turn on it's perfect. everything works as it should

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- Green light, no fan spin but sometimes boots. VERY temperamental
threads.message: wait now it works with original charger too. hmmm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- Green light, no fan spin but sometimes boots. VERY temperamental
threads.message:
once I get the issue sorted once it works indefinitely even after shutting down. I have scraped the contact points around ISL earlier. Before I did that the machine showed no sign of life. now it's booting properly once I get it going. I have noticed that regardless of a real and fake charger, if I plug it in, the first time it will never work. but if i do it a second time it always works. It's only an issue when the battery has been disconnected before. Is this just a quirk with this particular machine? Like i said it was dead before I started messing around ISL. 

I would just like to know what exactly happened

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- Green light, no fan spin but sometimes boots. VERY temperamental
threads.message:
First, check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28.
The issue looks like leakage and original detects it and stop to power the board.
Check around <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>, R/<DIODE>D7012</DIODE>...
Post exact values of <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86, measured onboard.
Possibly <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> need to be changed.
